case_name: Travancore Rubber and Tea Co., Ltd. v. State of Kerala

facts.text: Petitions Nos. 237 to 239 of 1961 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petitions Nos. 237 to 239 of 61. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Travancore Rubber and Tea Co., Ltd. and one of its directors and members filed these petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The Travancore Rubber and Tea Co., Ltd., hereinafter called the company, and one of Its directors and members, have filed these petitions praying for a declaration

facts.text: Petitioners pray for declaration that Agricultural Income Tax Amendment Act, 1961 (Act IX of 1961) is null and void.

anchor.surface_text: praying for a declaration that the Agricultural Income Tax  Amendment  Act, 1961  Act IX of 1961 , hereinafter called the Amendment Act, enacted by the Kerala State Legislature, is null and void

facts.text: Petitioners seek orders restraining State of Kerala and Assistant Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, Kottayam from enforcing Amendment Act.

anchor.surface_text: and for the issue of appropriate orders to the respondents viz., the State of Kerala and the Assistant Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, Kottayam, restraining them, their agents and servants from enforcing or acting upon the provisions

facts.text: Petitioners seek refund of tax illegally assessed and collected.

anchor.surface_text: of the aforesaid Amendment Act against the company and for refund of tax illegally assessed and companylected from the company.

facts.text: Company's business consists of owning and managing rubber and tea estates in Kerala State.

anchor.surface_text: The business of the company companysists of owning and managing rubber and tea estates situate in Kerala State.

facts.text: Company assessed to agricultural income-tax for accounting years 1950, 1951, 1952 corresponding to assessment years 1951-52, 1952-53, 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: The company was assessed to agricultural income-tax under the Agricultural Income-tax Act 1950  originally the Travancore- Cochin Agricultural Income-tax Act XXII of 1950, amended as the Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950 by Act VIII of 1957 of the Kerala Legislature , hereinafter called the Agricultural Income-tax Act, with respect to its income derived from its rubber plantations in the accounting years 1950, 1951 and 1952, companyresponding to the assessment years 1951-1952, 1952- 53 and 1953-54.

facts.text: Assessing authority did not deduct expenses for upkeep of immature rubber plants in assessment year 1953-54 but allowed in other two years.

anchor.surface_text: The assessing authority did number deduct the expenses incurred in the upkeep and maintenance of the imma- ture rubber plants in the assessment of the income for the assessment year 1953-54, but allowed it in the assessment with respect to the other two years.

facts.text: Cases referred to High Court of Kerala under s. 60 of Agricultural Income-tax Act at request of Income-tax Department and company.

anchor.surface_text: At the request of the Income-tax Department and of the company, cases were referred to the High Court of Kerala in accordance with s. 60 of the Agricultural Income-tax Act.

facts.text: High Court of Kerala decided against the company holding such expenditure not deductible.

anchor.surface_text: The High companyrt decided against the company holding that such expenditure was number to be deducted in companyputing the agricultural income.

facts.text: Supreme Court held on December 15, 1960 that expenses allowable under s. 5(j) (Travancore Rubber and Tea Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner).

anchor.surface_text: The company came to this Court against the order of the High Court and this Court held, by its judgment dated December 15, 1960 The Travancore Rubber and Tea Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax, Kerala  1  that such expenses were allowable under s. 5 j  of the Agricultural Income-tax Act in companyputing the assessable income.

facts.text: Governor of Kerala promulgated an ordinance subsequently repealed by Amendment Act of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Governor of Kerala State promulgated an ordinance which was subsequently repealed by the Amendment Act of 1961.

facts.text: Amendment Act deemed to have come into effect from April 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Amendment Act was deemed to have companye into effect from April 1, 1951.

facts.text: Amendment Act s.2 adds Explanation 2 to s.5 disallowing deduction for immature plants.

anchor.surface_text: By its s. 2, Explanation 2 was added to s. 5 of the Agricultural Income- tax Act. That Explanation reads Nothing companytained in this section shall be deemed to entitle a person deriving agricultural income to deduction of any expenditure laid out or expended for the cultivation, upkeep or maintenance of immature plants from which numberagricultural income has been derived during the previous year.

facts.text: Amendment Act s.3 deems previous assessments without such deduction as valid.

anchor.surface_text: By S. 3, assessments previously made on the basis that such expenses were number to be allowed in companyputing agricultural income were deemed to be valid.

facts.text: Company wrote to Income-tax Commissioner on February 22, 1961 for refund based on SC judgment.

anchor.surface_text: On February 22, 1961, the company, on the basis of the judgment of this Court, wrote to the Income-tax Commissioner for refunding the excess tax which had been realised.

facts.text: Commissioner replied on June 20, 1961 that claim not maintainable due to Amendment Act.

anchor.surface_text: It got the reply, dated June 20, 1961, that its claim for refund was number maintainable so long as the orders of assessment were number varied or reversed by any companyetent authority and that the claim was also number tenable in view of the provisions companytained in the Amendment Act.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 1, 1962 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 1. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR.DAYAL,J.

facts.text: Agricultural Income-tax Act originally Travancore-Cochin Act XXII of 1950, amended by Act VIII of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: under the Agricultural Income-tax Act 1950  originally the Travancore- Cochin Agricultural Income-tax Act XXII of 1950, amended as the Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950 by Act VIII of 1957 of the Kerala Legislature , hereinafter called the Agricultural Income-tax Act,

facts.text: State Legislature power from Entry 46, List II, Seventh Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The State Legislature derives power to tax agricultural income by virtue of Entry number 46, List 11, Seventh Schedule, of the Constitution.

facts.text: Explanation 2 enacted after SC decision in Travancore Rubber case.

anchor.surface_text: Such an intention of the Legislature is manifest as Explanation 2 was enacted after the decision of this Court in the Travancore Rubber And Tea Co. Ltd., case 1  to the effect that such expenses are to be deducted

facts.text: Company contends Explanation 2 discriminatory under Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: The next companytention for the appellant is that Explanatin 2 is discriminatory and companytravenes the provisions of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Court held Explanation 2 not discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing discriminatory in the provisions of. Explanation 2 to s. 5. It is applicable to agricultural income derived from all crops except tea.

facts.text: In Karimtharuvi Tea Estates case, court held Explanation 2 not apply to tea plantations.

anchor.surface_text: The question of the applicability of Explanation 2 to s. 5 to the agricultural income derive from tea plantations was before us for determination in The Karimtharuvi Tea Estates Ltd., Kottayam v. The State of Kerala 1 . We have held in that case that Explanation 2 to s. 5 does number apply

issues.text: Whether the Agricultural Income Tax Amendment Act, 1961 (Act IX of 1961), enacted by the Kerala State Legislature, is null and void?

anchor.surface_text: Agricultural Income Tax  Amendment  Act, 1961  Act IX of 1961 , hereinafter called the Amendment Act, enacted by the Kerala State Legislature, is null and void

issues.text: Whether the State Legislature was competent to enact Explanation 2 to s. 5 of the Agricultural Income-tax Act to disallow deduction of expenditure on upkeep or maintenance of immature plants from which no agricultural income has been derived?

anchor.surface_text: Explanation 2 was added to s. 5 of the Agricultural Income- tax Act. That Explanation reads Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to entitle a person deriving agricultural income to deduction of any expenditure laid out or expended for the cultivation, upkeep or maintenance of immature plants from which no agricultural income has been derived during the previous year.

issues.text: Whether, apart from s.5(j), the word 'income' in Entry 82 List I and Entry 46 List II of the Seventh Schedule means net receipts after deducting necessary expenses for earning it?

anchor.surface_text: Entry No. 82 of List 1 and Entry No. 46 of List II, of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether Explanation 2 to s.5 is discriminatory and contravenes Art.14 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: Explanatin 2 is discriminatory and contravenes the provisions of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether Explanation 2 to s.5 discriminates between agricultural income from rubber plantations and tea plantations in violation of Art.14?

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing discriminatory in the provisions of. Explanation 2 to s. 5. It is applicable to agricultural income derived from all crops except tea... The difference in the provisions for the computation of agricultural income from tea plantations and from rubber plantations is therefore based on good reasons.

arguments.claim: If Explanation 2 does not apply to tea, it discriminates between rubber and tea incomes violating Art.14

anchor.surface_text: It was argued that if such be the view of this Court, the Explanation would bringing about discrimination between agricultural income arising from rubber plantations and similar income arising from tea plantations and that therefore the Explanation would companytravene the provisions of Art. 14 of the Constitution.

arguments.qualifiers: fairly conceded if based on special provisions
arguments.court_reasoning: Karimtharuvi Tea Estates holds Explanation 2 not apply to tea due to special rules under s.59 Income-tax Act for apportionment; difference based on good reasons as tea income partly business

arguments.claim: Explanation 2 applies to agricultural income from all crops except tea and not discriminatory

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing discriminatory in the provisions of. Explanation 2 to s. 5. It is applicable to agricultural income derived from all crops except tea.

arguments.claim: Provisions for tea and rubber differ rationally due to special rules for tea income computation

anchor.surface_text: The provision for the companyputation of agricultural income from tea plantations has to be different and is to be found in the rules made under s. 59 3  of the Income-tax Act for determining the proportions of agricultural income and income from business in the entire income from the sale of tea.

arguments.claim: Legislature intended no deduction for immature plants as Explanation 2 enacted post-SC judgment allowing it

anchor.surface_text: Such an intention of the Legislature is manifest as Explanation 2 was enacted after the decision of this Court in the Travancore Rubber And Tea Co. Ltd., case 1  to the effect that such expenses are to be deducted

holdings.text: The State Legislature was competent to enact Explanation 2 to s. 5 and thereby provide for the non-deduction of the expenses incurred in the upkeep or maintenance of immature plants from which no income has been derived in the accounting year.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the State Legislature was competent to enact Explanation 2 to s. 5 and thereby provide for the non-deduction of the expenses incurred in the upkeep or maintenance of immature plants from which no

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature has full power under Entry 46 List II to tax agricultural income as defined per IT Act and prescribe deductions; Explanation clarifies no deduction for immature plants, enacted post-SC judgment allowing it.

holdings.text: The Amendment Act is valid and not null and void.

anchor.surface_text: The State Legislature derives power to tax agricultural income by virtue of Entry 46, List 11, Seventh Schedule, of the Constitution. Article 366 1  defines agricultural income to mean agricultural income as defined for the purpose of the enactments relating to Indian income-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State competent to amend AIT Act including adding Explanation 2 and validating prior assessments via s.3; petitions for declaration of invalidity and injunction rejected.

holdings.text: The word 'income' in Entries 82 List I and 46 List II has a very wide meaning and is not restricted to net receipts after deducting necessary expenses.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore clear that the word income in the relevant provisions of the Constitution has a very wide meaning and is not restricted in its meaning as suggested for the petitioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Navinchandra Mafatlal v. CIT, 'income' naturally means any profit or gain received, not cut down by judicial interpretations or legislative practice in other contexts.

holdings.text: There is nothing discriminatory in the provisions of Explanation 2 to s. 5; it is applicable to agricultural income derived from all crops except tea.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniform application to all non-tea crops; tea treated differently due to special rules.

holdings.text: The provisions of Explanation 2 are not discriminatory against agricultural income from rubber plantations.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Difference with tea justified by special provisions under s.59 Income-tax Act for apportioning tea income between agriculture and business; rational classification upheld per Art.14 twin test; follows Karimtharuvi Tea Estates.
